questions.text: A 28-year-old swimming pool worker presents to the dermatology clinic with a lesion on his left hand which is mostly painless but has gradually increased in size as shown in the image. He recalls sustaining a minor cut while cleaning a pool about a month ago. Which of the following is a characteristic feature of this condition?

choices.text: Non tender, erythematous nodules along lymphatic vessels
Vesicular rash with a linear distribution

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non tender, erythematous nodules along lymphatic vessels

Explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests Swimming pool granuloma or Fish tank granuloma, which is caused by Mycobacterium marinum following exposure to contaminated water sources such as swimming pools or aquariums.

  • It is characterized by erythematous, painless nodules along lymphatic vessels of the affected area.
  • Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen may reveal granulomatous inflammation.
  • Treated with clarithromycin + ethambutol.

Erythematous nodules with central clearing (Option A) are a characteristic feature of erythema migrans. They typically present as a red, expanding rash with central clearing, often resembling a bull's eye or target-like appearance, which is seen in Lyme disease.

Vesicular rash with a linear distribution (Option C) is a characteristic feature of herpes zoster (shingles), a viral infection caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus. It typically presents with a painful vesicular rash that follows a dermatomal distribution (i.e., along the path of a sensory nerve).

Target-like lesions with central clearing (Option D) are a characteristic feature of erythema multiforme, which various factors, including infections, medications, and autoimmune disorders can trigger.

questions.text: A 35-year-old construction worker presents with a painless lesion on his right forearm following sustaining a minor abrasion while working with bricks a few weeks ago. Physical examination reveals a shallow ulcer with undermined edges. Acid-fast bacilli staining of a biopsy specimen from the lesion is positive. Which of the following types of cutaneous tuberculosis is most likely responsible for this presentation?

choices.text: Exogenous with previous exposure to MTB
Exogenous with no previous exposure to MTB

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Exogenous with no previous exposure to MTB

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario suggests Tuberculosis chancre, a multibacillary, exogenous cutaneous TB that occurs in individuals with no previous sensitization to TB.
  • It presents with an ulcer with undermined edges and is analogous to Ghon’s focus on pulmonary TB.

Cutaneous TB is classified into three categories:

Exogenous: The source of TB is outside the body. It is further divided into two types based on previous exposure to MTB.

Tuberculosis chancre

Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis

  • No previous exposure to MTB
  • No immunity present
  • Multibacillary
  • Previous exposure to MTB
  • Strong immunity is present
  • Paucibacillary

Endogenous: The source of TB is inside the body

Tuberculids: Cutaneous hypersensitivity response to mycobacteria

Exogenous with previous exposure to MTB (Option A):

  • Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis, a paucibacillary exogenous cutaneous TB, occurs in previously sensitised individuals with strong immunity; hence it is not the correct option for the given condition.
  • It presents as a painless, slowly progressive, red or brown warty, hyperkeratotic plaque with a verrucous or papillomatous surface.

Endogenous cutaneous TB (Option C): The source of the given clinical condition is exogenous, not endogenous.

Endogenous cutaneous TB is classified into three categories based on its mode of spread.

Contiguous

Autoinoculation

Hematogenous

Scrofuloderma:

  • Endogenous spread from the cervical lymph node.
  • Multibacillary.
  • Most common in children but occur in all age groups.

Periorificial TB:

  • It is a multibacillary lesion.
  • This is due to the bacterium being directly inoculated into the skin through minor trauma or breaks in the skin around the orifices.

 

Lupus vulgaris:

  • Paucibacillary.
  • Presents as reddish-brown papules, nodules, or plaques on the skin.
 

TB Gumma:

  • Multibacillary
  • Presents as painless, indurated subcutaneous nodules or abscesses.

Tuberculids​​​​​​​ (Option D): These are cutaneous hypersensitivity reactions to mycobacterium tuberculosis due to hematogenous spread, not exogenous sources. Examples include

  • Lichen scrofulosorum (Micropapular)
  • Papulonecrotic tuberculid (Papular)
  • Erythema Induratum of Bazin (Nodular)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a slowly progressive, verrucous plaque on her left foot. She has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis treated several years ago. On examination, the lesion appears well-defined, hyperkeratotic, and verrucous, with a papillomatous surface as shown in the image. All of the following statements are true about this condition except?

choices.text: Anatomist's wart is the other name
Antitubercular therapy is used in the management

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Post-primary tuberculosis with poor immunity.

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario and the image suggest the diagnosis of Tuberculosis verrucous cutis which is also known as Prosecutor's wart, Anatomist's wart (Option A), Verruca necrogenica, and Warty tuberculosis.
  • It is a form of Cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs after direct inoculation of the mycobacteria into the skin of a previously sensitized host with good immunity against the bacillus. (Option B)
  • It is a paucibacillary lesion (Option C), and inoculation typically occurs from an exogenous source.
  • In adults, TBVC most frequently develops on the acral extremities; the fingers and dorsum of the hands are commonly affected, while in children, the ankles or buttocks are frequent sites for lesion occurrence.
  • It presents as a painless, slowly progressive, red or brown warty, hyperkeratotic plaque with a verrucous or papillomatous surface and it grows via peripheral extension.
  • On histopathological examination, it is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with epithelioid histiocytes, giant cells, and caseous necrosis(caseating granulomas).
  • It can be treated with Antitubercular drugs (Option D).

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging, painless lesion on her neck. She had a history of pulmonary tuberculosis and involvement of underlying nodes, which was treated successfully 3 years ago. On examination, there is a firm, erythematous plaque with overlying crusting and shallow ulcerations shown in the image. There are also enlarged, non-tender cervical lymph nodes palpable on the same side of the neck. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scrofuloderma

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and the image suggest a diagnosis of Scrofuloderma, which is caused by the direct extension of an infection (endogenous spread) to the skin from the underlying TB focus (Lymph node, bone joint).

  • It is a multibacillary manifestation and is the most common form of cutaneous TB in children, although it can occur in any age group.
  • It often presents as painless subcutaneous swellings and ruptures into the overlying skin resulting in discharging sinuses or undermined ulcers or fibrotic scars.
  • The most common focus of infection is the cervical lymph node.
  • The most common site is the neck and axilla.
  • Biopsy reveals positive staining for acid-fast bacilli and characteristic caseating granulomas seen.

Actinomycosis (Option B):

  • This is a bacterial infection (Actinomyces israelii) that often presents as chronic indurated, subcutaneous nodules or abscesses with draining sinus tracts that may contain sulfur granules.
  • While both scrofuloderma and actinomycosis can lead to suppurative skin lesions, actinomycosis typically lacks the nodular lesions with central caseation seen in scrofuloderma.

Sporotrichosis (Option C):

  • It is a fungal infection caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. It usually presents as painless, pruritic papules or nodules at the site of inoculation, often following trauma from plant material.
  • Over time, these lesions may ulcerate and develop a linear arrangement along the lymphatic channels.
  • Unlike scrofuloderma, sporotrichosis does not typically exhibit central caseation.

Pyoderma gangrenosum (Option D) :

  • This rare, non-infectious skin condition is characterized by painful ulcers with undermined borders.
  • It is associated with various underlying systemic diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, or hematologic malignancies.
  • Histopathology typically shows a neutrophilic infiltrate without evidence of infection, vasculitis, or granuloma formation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a large erythematous, scaly plaque with deep-seated nodules on her buttock, as shown in the image. The lesion gradually progressed over 4 years, exhibiting scarring and atrophy in some areas. Diascopy of the nodules reveals an "apple jelly" nodules. She has a history of a positive tuberculin skin test but no active tuberculosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lupus vulgaris

Explanation:

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Lupus vulgaris which is a chronic form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitized individuals with moderate immunity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

  • These lesions usually appear as well-defined, erythematous to reddish-brown plaques or nodules with smooth, slightly scaly, or verrucous surfaces and may have active, raised margins.
  • They may initially appear as small papules or nodules that gradually enlarge and coalesce to form larger plaques.
  • Often exhibits induration due to the underlying granulomatous inflammation and atrophy due to underlying tissue destruction by the tuberculosis infection.
  • The center of the lesion may show atrophy and scarring.
  • Diagnosis is often confirmed by histopathological examination of skin biopsy specimens, which typically show caseating granulomas with acid-fast bacilli.
  • Diascopy shows characteristic ‘apple jelly nodules’.
  • Treated with Antitibercular therapy.

Fig. Apple Jelly Nodule on diascopy


 

Psoriasis (Option B):

  • This typically presents as well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, most commonly on extensor surfaces and scalp.
  • It is associated with systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis and does not produce apple jelly nodules on diascopy, spitz sign positive.

 

Fig. Psoriasis


 

Lupus pernio (Option C):

  • It is a distinctive form of chronic cutaneous sarcoidosis, a multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas.
  • It typically presents as persistent, violaceous or dusky-red, indurated plaques or nodules, often involving the nose, cheeks, lips, and ears.
  • It can present with apple jelly nodules on diascopy, but histopathological examination reveals non-caseating granuloma.

 

Fig. Lupus pernio


 

Granuloma Annulare (Option D):

  • It is a benign, self-limiting dermatosis characterized by the formation of dermal granulomas, which are typically devoid of necrosis.
  • Typically presents as asymptomatic or minimally pruritic, erythematous to skin-coloured papules or plaques.

 

Fig. Granuloma Annulare

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with an erythematous plaque over the dorsum of hand that has been there for 4 years and is slowly progressing. Examination revealed a well-demarcated, indurated, annular-shaped plaque with irregular borders that was progressing towards one side and scarring on another border. Which of the following statements is FALSE about this condition?

choices.text: It occurs in a previously sensitized patient
Apple jelly nodules can be seen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) It is a multibacillary lesion

Explanation:

Based on the history and the image provided, the diagnosis is Lupus vulgaris and it is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary (not multibacillary) form of cutaneous tuberculosis.

  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous TB seen in adults (Most common in females).
  • Causative organisms: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium bovis.

Pathogenesis :

  • Route of spread: Endogenous spread or from exogenous inoculation.
  • It occurs in a previously sensitized individual with an increased cell-mediated immunity to tuberculin. (Option B)

Clinical features:

  • Presents as a single or a group of erythematous violaceous annular plaques with central scarring and atrophy with active margins. (Option C)
  • The periphery shows erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules. (Option D)
  • Most commonly seen in the buttocks, upper extremities, and face.
  • Papules may recur within scarred areas, enlarging and coalescing into large, firm, elevated plaques.

Complications:

  • Secondary scarring and squamous cell carcinoma may develop rarely.

Treatment :

  • Anti-tubercular drugs.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child presented in dermatology OPD with a micro papular rash on the trunk without any necrosis or itching. The Mantoux test is positive. Histopathology examination shows perifollicular non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following statements is false about its diagnosis?

choices.text: The most common site is the trunk
It is not a type of lichen planus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Commonly seen in adults

Explanation: 
Based on the clinical history and image, the diagnosis points to Lichen scrofulosorum, a rare form of tuberculid (Option C), commonly seen in children (not in adults).

Fig. Lichen Scrofulosorum showing annular and plaque‐like lesions with strong tuberculin reaction

 

Lichenoid variety of Lichen Scrofulosorum

 

  • Lichen scrofulosorum presents with asymptomatic, lichenoid-grouped papules, often perifollicular in distribution. (Option D)
  • The trunk is the most common site for these lesions. (Option B)
  • Healing typically occurs without scarring.
  • Positive Mantoux test indicates previous exposure to tuberculosis antigens.
  • Biopsy reveals superficial dermal granulomas surrounding hair follicles. These granulomas contain epithelioid cells, lymphocytes, and occasional giant cells, typically without caseation.
  • Treatment involves a course of antitubercular therapy: 2 months of HRZE followed by 4 months of HRE.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female presented in dermatology OPD with bilateral nodular lesions and ulceration on her calf. On examination, tenderness was noticed. The Mantoux test was positive, and the culture for M. tuberculosis was negative. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Erythema induratum of Bazin

Explanation:

The given clinical history suggests a diagnosis of Erythema induratum of Bazin. It is a type of tuberculid whose cause is not fully understood. It is believed to be a hypersensitivity reaction to Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigens.

  • It is most common in middle-aged females.
  • It presents as recurrent nodular and ulcerative lesions that are usually localized to the lower legs(posterior calves).
  • Biopsy reveals Lobular panniculitis and vasculitis.
  • Tuberculids can be considered to be cutaneous hypersensitivity reactions to hematogenous dissemination of M. tuberculosis or its antigens from a primary source in an individual with strong anti-tuberculous cell‐mediated immunity.
  • Patients with tuberculids typically have a good response to anti-tuberculous therapy.

(Option B) Lichen Scrofulosorum:

  • It is a type of tuberculid that consists of grouped lichenoid papules on the trunk unlike nodular and ulcerative lesions of erythema induratum of Bazin.
  • Most common in children.
  • The lesions are mainly perifollicular and heal without scarring.

(Option C) Papulonecrotic tuberculid:

  • This is also a type of tuberculid, but it presents as necrotic papules on the extremities, which differs from the nodular lesions of erythema induratum of Bazin.
  • Most commonly found in adults.
  • Biopsy may reveal obliterative vasculitis (vascular inflammation) and thrombosis.

 

(Option D) Erythema nodosum:

  • Erythema nodosum presents as recurrent crops of tender, erythematous, subcutaneous nodules on the extensor aspect of extremities.
  • Ulceration and atrophic scarring as seen in Erythema induratum of Bazin are distinctly absent in Erythema nodosum.

.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with an erythematous plaque with central scarring and an advancing edge on her face. She reports a gradual progression of lesions over several months. Biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following drugs will be started as a part of treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rifampicin

Explanation:

  • The clinical picture shows an erythematous plaque with central scarring and an advancing edge, which suggests a clinical diagnosis of Lupus vulgaris.
  • Rifampicin is an antibiotic that is part of the standard Anti-Tuberculous Therapy (ATT), started in this patient.
  • It is used in combination with other medications, such as Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol, to treat cutaneous tuberculosis, such as lupus vulgaris.

Amphotericin B (Option A):

  • Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication used for serious systemic fungal infections caused by Candida species, Aspergillus species, Cryptococcus neoformans, Histoplasma capsulatum, and other fungi.
  • It is not indicated in the treatment of cutaneous tuberculosis.

Itraconazole (Option B):

  • Itraconazole is an antifungal agent that is commonly used for fungal infections of the skin like dermatophytosis.
  • It would not be effective in treatment against mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Minocycline (Option D) :

  • It is a tetracycline antibiotic with anti-inflammatory properties often used for acne-vulgaris.
  • It is not the treatment of choice for mycobacterial infections.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a large painless ulcer on the lower extremity with a necrotic base and undermined edges. His family reports that they live near a wetland area in a region known to have cases of similar ulcers. There has been no response to standard treatment for common bacterial skin infections. A smear from the lesion shows acid-fast bacilli. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Buruli ulcer

Explanation:

It is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans, which is endemic to wetland areas.

  • It presents as a painless ulcer with necrosis and undermined edges.
  • Necrosis is due to a cytotoxin, Myolactone, released by the organism
  • ﻿Acid-fast bacilli in a smear from the lesion support the diagnosis.
  • The four main diagnostic laboratory tests for Buruli ulcer are direct smear (with acid‐fast stains, auramine O or Ziehl–Neelsen), culture at 32°C, histopathology (lympho-epithelioid cell proliferation and panniculitis with characteristic fat necrotic changes), PCR (highest sensitivity).

Treatment:

Small ulcers(<5cm)

Rifampicin + Clarithromycin/Streptomycin for 8 weeks

Large ulcers (>5cm)

Surgery is recommended along with antibiotic therapy.


Cutaneous Tuberculosis (Option B): Although cutaneous tuberculosis is caused by an acid-fast bacillus (Mycobacterium tuberculosis), it typically presents in areas with a high prevalence of tuberculosis.


Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (Option C):

  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis causes skin ulcers, but these are typically painful and often associated with travel to endemic areas, such as the Middle East or South America.
  • ﻿﻿A smear would show Leishmania parasites, not acid-fast bacilli.


​​​​​​​Diabetic Ulcer (Option D) : Diabetic ulcers are typically found on pressure points of the feet, are associated with neuropathy and vascular disease, and do not usually present with undermined edges or a necrotic base unless secondarily infected.
